Carrie Anne, you're brilliant and great fun to listen to, but you left out the Amiga Computer. After the Commodore 64, the Amiga became popular as a personal computer on par with the Mac,  the Atari ST, and the IBM PC. It has a place in personal computer history as the first to offer a color interface and improved audio compared to other systems. It was the Amiga that inspired Apple and IBM to improve their graphics and audio.

You kinda missed the fact that the IBM pc wasn't intended to be an open design. It had a proprietary BIOS that prevented IBM software from being run on a  PC without an IBM BIOS. It wasn't until Compaq created a clone of the IBM bios that the IBM eco system opened up. You made it sound like IBM was creating this open eco system out of the goodness of their own hearts where in reality that wasn't their intent.

There's two broad categories for how you can handle programs when designing a language.   Category 1 is compilation, which translates the whole program into machine code before you run it. It produces fast code, but it's complicated and can use a lot of memory while compiling, and provides a lot of opportunities for optimising things.  Category 2 is interpretation, which translates it as needed. It's slow, can't be optimised as much, but tends to be simpler and use less memory, which can be desirable in a restricted system, such as the Apollo Guidance Computer, which got the astronauts to the moon.  There are also hybrid approaches which use a bit of both, too. Java, for instance, compiles to an intermediate bytecode, which then gets run through an interpreter.
First of all, thanks for the reply!  Second...I don't understand what your getting at.  Are you saying the interpreter isn't the kernal of today's operating systems?

Yes, that's what he's saying. Interpreters aren't operating systems, they're programs like any others. The OS is below that. An interpreter is a program that takes human-code and translates it into machine-code on the fly, so the computer can run it. With that, people could write their own programs without knowledge of Assembler or even more basic machine code, and use easier and more understandable programming languages like BASIC.

As I understand it, that's what a kernal does as well.  A kernal takes the shell commands, and translates them into a language the machine can understand.  Is this not the case?  Also, thanks for the reply!

mattig89ch a kernel is just part of an operating system program. It isn’t built in to hardware, if that is what you are getting at. You can write programs in assembler or C compiled directly into memory, no kernel necessary.

My college roommate had an Apple Jr. in our dorm room.  My grades were directly linked to my access to that computer.  I could type and would trade typing her papers  for computer time so I didn't have to hike all the way across campus to the computer lab and take my chances getting on one of the limited computers.  Thus began a life-long tradition of working at the computer in my pajamas.  My friend Jay, who went to John's Hopkins University, had first an Apple 2E then was the first person I knew who got the new Apple McIntosh.

Hikigaya Kun Windows is an operating system that you can install on any machine capable of running a set of commands (i.e. x86). On the other hand you cant use mac unless you buy a set of hardware that is only available from Apple and is unreasonably overpriced.

Most people don't have the capacity to visualise or even know what they want until they are presented a standardised solution such as GUI's. Apples ability to provide a solid user experience and branding is what allows it to be one of the biggest companies in the world today.  It's easy to prefer a certain aspect when it comes to these topics, however that doesn't make other architectures wrong or worse than what you prefer.   I like the idea of MS Windows where I can do whatever I want, however I dislike the volatile and bad written software and horrible CLI.  I prefer Linux systems but I dislike the compatibility issues with needed software such as MS word and Photoshop for example without running a simulator like WINE.  I prefer Mac OS because it provides a solid user experience,  provides UNIX CLI tools and high quality applications. However I dislike the bloated price point and the lack of compatibility with non-apple devices.

Carrie Anne, You have omitted the most important group of microcomputers running at that time, Digital Research’s CP/M. VisiCalc that you mentioned as well as Wordstar and dBase were all originally written for CP/M. In fact it took a long time for businesses to give up their Kaypro's et al running CP/M. The IBM was not that well received and neither was MS-DOS.  The multi user version M/PM allowing multi-users over a network. It would take Microsoft years to catch up with that. To leave out CP/M is to take out a massive chunk of computer history. It’s like leaving out of history 1066 and the Norman invasion to school kids. [“A:” the CP/M prompt that was adopted by MS-Dos]

Apple, Pet and TRS-80 were introduced in the mid 70s, the C64 and the blooming homecomputer market took place in the early 80s, so half a decade later.

The Mad Tinkerer In Europe the C64, Amiga, Atari ST and Amstrad CPC were selling better than IBM compatibles in the mid to late 1980s, but by the early 1990s the IBM compatible caught up to the home market in Europe as well. The Amiga and Atari ST were particulary impressive, especially for gaming and other graphics applications. The IBM PC and Apple Macintosh were primarily geared towards the business market, while computers by the likes of Commodore and Atari were heavily promoted for home use.

CP/M was an operating system, not a microcomputer itself, and several of the microcomputers mentioned in this video could run it, including the Apple II (with Z-80 SoftCard, claimed to be the most popular CP/M platform by none other than Bill Gates), the Altair 8800, and the TSR-80, among many others.

Yup kinda shocked she didn't mention the Model 100/102/103 (I have a 103 that runs perfectly to this day). They're the first example of a laptop (computer you can use on your lap) and the Model 200 is the first example of the modern laptop form factor.

The reason I mentioned CP/M was because it was the business standard. In our office we mainly used Kaypro’s and that remained the standard long after the IBM PC. Computers like the TRS 80 and the C64 (Don’t forget the VIC20) were hobbyist computers you would not find them in business offices. I cut my teeth on a Sony MSX. But it was the Business world that had the buying power that drove development.

Mike Meyer You are correct. That is why I stressed the "commercial" bit. Microcomputers, such as C64, Atari 400/800 and Spectrum were crucial in introducing the "wider audience" to computers and programming - even if they weren't revolutionary in strictly technological terms. The very fact that there are still people making demos on each of the platforms mentioned above (as well as people willing to spend a better part of the day on debating which is better) is a testament to that.
"Visicalc, the first-ever spreadsheet program, was never made available for CP/M. Another company, Sorcim, rose to the challenge and created its Supercalc." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CP/M

To me, it's not about which computer was best (personally I'm pretty happy open arch model won out - not necessarily a fan of x86 though) but which systems are kinda obvious and really shouldn't be left out here. It's also going to warrant a comment if she starts talking about handhelds and leaves out the Newton, iPaq, and Palm. And here again, I'm quite happy I don't have to use those systems anymore but they made good innovation for the time and that really shouldn't be forgotten.

There's a very important inaccuracy here. IBM didn't set out to create an open platform and allow competition with themselves. They just made a platform that was easy enough for Compaq to reverse-engineer, and failed to secure an exclusivity deal with Microsoft, leading to the explosion of IBM-compatibles *against IBM's will*. Also, rolling Dell in with the era of Compaq is way anachronistic; Dell was much later in the game, barely a name in the consumer world until the late 90s.

Missing in the video was the reason why Apple won and the others lost: Apple II costed $1000 and the others $500, but the Apple’s floppy drive costed $500 each and the others costed $1000 (more than the computer), the floppy drive was pure Wozniak genius work, so it costed so little. So for the same price you would get a much better computer, with card expansibility and color graphics. If you wanted 2 floppy drives (common, at the time), it was a no brainer!

This is a yes AND no situation - the ability to make IBM-compatible computers isn't by design. But the open architecture was intentional to IBM to break the computer into components that they could swap/upgrade/cheapen over time. (i.e. if they found a new better way to build a printer, they could as long as the IBM printer group followed the IBM PC group's printer interface spec)
